title: How to tell if someone has linked my phone to theirs - Quora

response.answer_text: Linked as in hacked? Several ways any or all of these could indicate a hacked phone: You notice apps on your phone that are new that you and your phone manufacturer or service provider did not install.Your phone is ALWAYS warm or hot to the touch even when you're no using it (because your phone IS being used by a background app or another person)You see apps suddenly turning on by themselves and shutting down really quickly like you started them and them quit them.Your phone frequently cycles on and off for no reason (this could be a memory block issue too, not always caused by hacking)Passwords are changed that you didn't changeYou haven't added a significant amount of data to your phone but you're suddenly out of storage space. Again not always indicative of hacking. Check to make sure you haven't synced your phone to install apps purchased on another device automatically (like a tablet)Your phone is suddenly so slow it's near unusable. I feel like a broken record lol but again, not always caused by hacking.You hear strange noises or crackling when taking and making phone calls.You notice charges to the App Store or worse, your bank account or credit cards that you didn't make.The most obvious: you get a message that you've been hacked and they want money to give you access to your phone again.Theres probably more red flags to look for, but those are the ones I can think of off the top of my head. If you suspect you've been hacked there are steps you should take: your first instinct will be to change passwords. YES but do it on ANOTHER DEVICE not your phone. If you're hacked they'll be able to see the new password if you use your phone.Go into settings and wipe your phone. Hopefully you've already backed it up or are able to wireless back it up. DO NOT connect the device to your computer to back it up unless you are able to use a computer that has no info on it that a hacker would want. If you connect a hacked device to another device there's a good chance the hacker will then take control of that computer.I suggest a clean install and manually adding anything you want on the phone back onto it. If you install from a backup AFTER the hacker had access, they can probably still access your phone.Ways hackers can get into your phone (aka have you done these recently?): used free wifi AND logged into sensitive sites like bank accounts. Sometimes they will control a wifi hotspot and give you a fraudulent erosion of the site your visiting in order to obtain your passwordsUsed a public charging station. Apparently hackers can get into your phone through the USB cables now too.Answered any suspicious emails or gone to a phishing website by accident.Jail broken your phone and/or installed apps that were not in the iTunes or google play store.Again, I'm sure there's more things I'm missing in this list, but hopefully this will get you started in figuring out what is going on. If you have an apple device, the Genius Bar will assist you, regardless of whether your phone is still covered by a warranty or not, in determine whether or not you are indeed hacked. Not sure about android phones though, I think you're on your own if that's the phone you have. Good luck! I'm keeping my fingers crossed that everything is okay!

Hi, I'm not sure what actually is the question but if u want to know about someone spying you through your phone, this might help Someone borrowed or took your phone, they may have installed phone control app that you might never know The app shows up with the name “Android System” in the applications manager so it doesn’t look suspicious. If you think someone could do something like this when you’re not with your phone, secure your phone with a passcode that isn’t easy to guess.Your phone is acting weirdly, Taking long time to reboot or shutting down, lighting up for no reason, suddenly getting much shorter battery life or running hot when you’re not using it may indicate hidden processes are running in the background.Your data usage skyrockets for no reason, This could be because your phone is checking in with someone else, using GPS and sending them text messages or emails that communicate where you are and what you’re doing.Once you got attack the best thing to do is factory reset, once you reset you will lose your data stored in the phone. You can backup your data but who knows one of your data has the same Spyware. After reset use strong passwords to prevent unauthorized access to your phone. There are free apps (app notifier for Android phone), which will email you when any apps are loaded or installed onto your phone. Hope this help, if not please make the question clear n simple….

You can have spyware installed on your phone. This cannot be done remotely - someone has to hold the phone and do it. It is difficult, but not impossible to remove this stuff. If you are thinking someone down the street can type in some magic password and suddenly all your text messages, emails and phone calls show up on their phone - forget it. This does not happen, cannot happen and phone companies have taken severe steps in the last 20 years to make sure the “cloning” that occurred in the 1990s never, ever happens again. Your phone cannot be “synched” with another device. There are substantial security measures in place to make sure things like this cannot happen. With spyware it is possible that everything your phone does is recorded and forwarded to someone at a later time. It does not occur in real time. But someone would get a report listing all of your text messages, for instance. It is illegal to do this with a phone you do not own, and if caught, the person installing this spyware could face a long time in prison. It is legal for a company phone to have this installed so the company knows how their property is being used. However, this isn’t cheap to do as there is a subscription cost for receiving the information which can be as high as $50 a month.

I agree with the other 2 answers. There are three other possibilities: (1) look in your phone settings under Connections - is Phone visibility turned on? If so, turn it off when you do not need it! (2) also in your phone's settings, look under Mobile Hotspot and Tethering. Are any toggles showing they are turned on (slid to the right)? Is Mobile Hotspot turned on? Is Bluetooth Tethering turned on? If either is on, turn them off when you do not need them! (3) also in your phone's settings, look under More Connection Settings: is Nearby Device Scanning turned on? If you do not regularly use any of the above, then them off when not in use. It may seem to be a pain to need to do any of the above but if you suspect that your phone has been hacked or linked to another without your permission and you cannot find any other solution to the problem, then unfortunately it is a pain that you will have to get used to.

It’s hard to tell 100% but it is possible. I believe what they could see after linking the phones depends on what you have toggled to be stored in the cloud. I myself just noticed that when I went to send an email to my mother in-law and I typed in the first letter in her name so I could pick it from the drop down list. Well she came up but not her name. Instead it said “mom”. Well I have a mom and that is how I have her in my phone…..mom. I wouldn’t have put my mother in-laws name as mom. So then I started at A and worked my way to Z. All the names that I know were not my contacts but were my boyfriends all had a i with a circle.The only thing that I have backed up to the cloud is my mail. So I’m guessing that is all that he could get assuming he used the cloud to link the phone. The same would happen if you were to try it on text messaging and contact list. That is sure fire way to know for sure.

Generally, this can’t happen, because of the way that carrier network and network security work. That being said, it is possible for the network to get a glitch and connect your phone number with someone else’s phone number. When that happens, you will likely get calls from people that are not intending to call you, and people who you know might try to call you and get someone strange. When this happens, the way to correct it is to contact your carrier, explain what’s happening, and they can do some computer magic to straighten things out. If you are using iPhone, it is possible for multiple people to sign into the same AppleID account. This is strongly recommended against, and can cause no end of confusion. I’ve seen this happen mostly with non-technical people and older customers. Ever since Apple made it possible to use Family Sharing to share purchases between different AppleID accounts, the use of one AppleID for multiple users has gone WAY down. Now, that all said, if someone maliciously cloned your phone (virtually impossible except by expensive equipment and a LOT of technical knowledge) there is not a lot that you can do other than monitor your phone bill to look for strange phone numbers being called.
There are various software on the market to use this. view my profile, i may be of help!

Use ‘Find my decice Sign in - Google Accounts ’, this Google service will list all linked devices to that account. When your email is signed in other phone, there will be syncing in both. Also the other phone can check your all activity through “Google My Activity” service. Most Important: check if any Spy App is not installed in your Phone. (Go to Google PlayStore and turn on Play Protect, it scans harmful apps which spy 🕵️ on)

Your phone cannot be synced with another device, however, your main account might be. It depends if you are using an Android or an iOS phone (I’m not quite sure about Windows phones, as I never had one before). To check if your account is linked with other devices visit Google Play store or App store respectively.

I know my phone is synced to my other devices because when I tap the ‘google search’ all the searches that I made with my phone that day show up on my computer. That is so cool. That includes any question I posed to google and any research topics I was searching for on my phone. I can also get a different phone and get all my contacts to show up on my new phone by signing into Google. Here's a link to a page that explains it quite well. Sync your apps with your Google Account Click or tap the blue line

Looks easy on TV, right? Don’t believe everything you see! I doubt that it’s anywhere near as easy as they show it. If you have important stuff on your phone, then hide it behind a 10-figure password (a tough one, with letters, figures and symbols, not your girlfriend’s birthday, LOL) Otherwise ask yourself: “is there really anything important on my phone?” Answer: “Unlikely!” If it happened to me, I’d say “you’re welcome to waste your time, idiot! Get a life!”

The software alterations will be on your settings, software information. If you Google what software is on your phone, or even an update that has arrived, and it doesn't exist, chances are that it's a modified custom one with a custom kernel that cannot be modified unless you have a very strong knowledge of coding and are confident about it. 1 incorrect thing, will completely destroy any use of the phone forever.

I'm not sure what you are asking. An iPhone can only sync with one computer, and cannot sync with any other devices other than a computer. So if it syncs with your computer it is not synced with any other. If you mean can it share content, it can share with all devices that are under your Apple ID. You can see what is registered with your Apple ID by going to iTunes, clicking on the button with your Apple ID in it, logging in, and then click the Manage Devices link.

It is not. You can't "link it" to any "device" other than your computer running iTunes. Well, and things like bluetooth headsets. What you want to find out is what devices are signed into your iCloud account / Apple ID. Log into your account at https://appleid.apple.com You will see on that page what devices are signed into your account.
Check the accounts. If you notice an account that isn’t yours, it is linked to someone else’s account, and they can view your location at any time.

Linked to your phone? Like thru your mobile hotspot? Go to settings, then mobile hotspot and if its on it should show you all connected devices. There are a few options there so you can limit how many devices can be connected at time, allowed devices, and set up a password so others can access your mobile hotspot/wifi signal.

If using Android open Settings/Security/Device Administrations. Any app(s) with priviledged capacities to do what you're suspecting would be listed here, even if such an app is installed in Stealth mode and not shown in your app drawer

Does not and cannot happen with recent phones. This could happen in the 1990s with ESN-based phones. With SIM cards, which cannot be altered, it can’t happen. Finally, I believe that should a duplicate SIM identifier appear on a carrier network both phones are immediately shut off from network access. The wireless carriers had enough in the 1990s. They lost millions and vowed never again.

If you mean that you are syncing data from your phone, e.g., contacts, mail, and photos, you are likely using a cloud service (like Apple uses) or an app that syncs using a data cable. One of the functions of most sync apps is to let you know when the sync is complete.
Phone is linked to others by network through satellites…. After it phoneay be connected through Bluetooth and telepine saved register while calling someone…
Check the permissions you've given to the apps or into the settings. Click on remove account from all devices and then change passwords.
Install a good antimalware. It’ll even scan those files which are running in phone’s background (without your knowledge) and then you can easily eliminate them.

Whats the phone model? You need to specify all details in detail.
